QuestionText: A body of mass $5 \text{ kg}$ is moving with a momentum of $10 \text{ kg m/s}$. A force of $0.2 \text{ N}$ acts on it in the direction of motion for $10 \text{ s}$. The increase in its kinetic energy is:
explanationText: Initial momentum $p_1 = 10 \text{ kg m/s}$. Initial velocity $v_1 = p_1/m = 10/5 = 2 \text{ m/s}$. Initial KE $K_1 = \frac{1}{2}mv_1^2 = \frac{1}{2}(5)(2^2) = 10 \text{ J}$. Force $F=0.2 \text{ N}$, time $t=10 \text{ s}$. Impulse $J = F \times t = 0.2 \times 10 = 2 \text{ Ns}$. Change in momentum $\Delta p = J = 2 \text{ kg m/s}$. Final momentum $p_2 = p_1 + \Delta p = 10 + 2 = 12 \text{ kg m/s}$. Final velocity $v_2 = p_2/m = 12/5 = 2.4 \text{ m/s}$. Final KE $K_2 = \frac{1}{2}mv_2^2 = \frac{1}{2}(5)(2.4^2) = \frac{1}{2}(5)(5.76) = 2.5 \times 5.76 = 14.4 \text{ J}$. Increase in KE $= K_2 - K_1 = 14.4 - 10 = 4.4 \text{ J}$.

QuestionText: An engine pumps water continuously through a hose. Water leaves the hose with a velocity $v$ and $m$ is the mass per unit length of the water jet. What is the rate at which kinetic energy is imparted to water?
explanationText: Mass per unit length is $m$. In time $\Delta t$, length of water jet leaving hose is $v \Delta t$. Mass of this water is $\Delta M = m (v \Delta t)$. Kinetic energy of this mass is $\Delta K = \frac{1}{2} (\Delta M) v^2 = \frac{1}{2} (mv\Delta t) v^2 = \frac{1}{2}mv^3\Delta t$. Rate at which kinetic energy is imparted $= \frac{\Delta K}{\Delta t} = \frac{1}{2}mv^3$.
